Laurel is a thirty nine year old trans gender woman.

And, while legal in this competition, her dominance
has a lot of people crying out "is this really fair?"
Is this an even playing field?
She was so dominant she beat her closest rival by lifting 40 more pounds than them.
And that's also because last year the international Olympics committee
changed the rules regarding trans athletes.
Under previous IOC guidelines
"athletes who transitioned from male to female
or vise versa were required to have reassignment
surgery followed by at least two years of hormone therapy
in order to be eligible to compete".
Now sex reassignment surgery is no longer required
and male to female athletes just have to show
that their testosterone level doesn't go above
a cut off point.
And that has to be documented at least one year
before their first competition.
And while there are people who argue that is the
right cut off point, if a person doesn't have over a certain

there is also a group of people that say
"no, its still not fair".
You can talk about male female equality in the world

People saying "look at the size difference between Laurel

And because those who have gone from male to female are

The unspecified victim here is probably Tom Brady.

Then let's talk about the newest ban to hit travel
and that is a device ban.
Many have been calling it the 'laptop ban'
but it actually covers a lot more than that.
So, I wanna explain this, especially because I see a lot of people freaking out going like
'Agh!  I got a trip to Florida next week, what do I do???'
Well, the first thing, if you're in the United States and you're traveling domestically,
or even if you're traveling internationally but you are leaving from the United States,
this does not affect you
UNTIL, after you leave the United States, and then when you want to fly back to the United States
you leave from one of ten international airports which are in Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Morocco, Kuwait, Qatar, the UAE
or even if you are not flying out of those airports, but you're flying back to the United States on one of these 9 airlines
then this ban affects you.
Also, for those of you who live in the UK, there is a similar ban in effect but it's for different airlines and it includes different locations.
But their ban list also includes Tunisia(?) and Lebanon, it doesn't include the UAE, Morocco, Kuwait, or Qatar.
And the devices you can't bring on the airplane that you have to check in your luggage include, yes, laptops,
but also 'tablets, E-Readers, Cameras, Portable DVD players'
*condescendingly* for those that use portable DVD players
'travel printers and scanners and electronic game units larger than a smartphone'.
So no Switch for you.
Now, as far as the reason for this, according to reports
an unnamed US official said "recent intelligence suggested an al Qaeda affiliate was
working on techniques for hiding explosives in batteries and battery compartments of electronic devices".
And so that's why we have the ban.
But this also seems to have some experts confused.
"Philip Baum, who is a UK-based aviation security analyst
said that, while it may be harder to activate laptop bombs if they're in the carriage of a plane,
gate screening is far more effective than cargo screening.
With gate screening you're dealing with smaller quantities and you've got a person in front of you.
And, this new measure does nothing to address the 'insider threats'" which is what was saw with the aviation
worker who helped with the bombing of a Somali plane last year.
And there's also been a lot of push-back from people who say 'I don't want my stuff stolen'.
And I understand their thinking, I don't trust to check anything that's expensive.
There was an analysis that I found that between 2010 and 2014 there were 30 thousand claims of property loss.
Back in 2014 there was a report that over 13 years the TSA had fired 507 baggage-screeners for steeling.
And those are just the ones who got caught!
And the TSA tries to combat this by sending bait-bags through
bags they send through with valuables to see if screeners steal them.
Between 2012 and 2014 they sent 35 hundred bags through,
ten items in that were stolen and the TSA even said 'that's ten items too many'.
To which people say 'well, if your stuff gets stolen, make sure that you always back up to the cloud.
Your 'lost items' will be covered by the airline' but that's also not completely true.
"Under an international treaty known as the Montreal Convention an airline's liability for or damage to a passenger's luggage is limited to the equivalent of about $1,360".
So, if you bought even the least expensive new MacBook Pro, it doesn't cover full cost.

somewhat all over the place ban that most likely is just uh more safety theater

Someone took screenshots and then sent it to the mother and said 'hey, is this your daughter?'
and then the mom had to take those photos and say 'a crime's being committed'.
